Head: thick cream colored foam. Color: red copper Aroma: hops, grain. Taste: smooth, grain. Palate: small bitter, lasting. Overall: very nice.
Did not enjoy this as much as the blue or the white, Still a dam good beer.
Very nice red/copper color with a great palate. A little less sweeter then its "Blue" brother, but very pleasant to drink during a light meal.

Bottle shared by ygtbsm94. Thanks Brad!

Best before 1997 (vintage 1994)

Its always fun to try old vintage beers. I thought this one mellowed out quite nicely and held up like a champ.

A: Very hazy, dark brown hue with a small head that generates a smattering of lacing on the glass. The beer also contains some black sediment, randomly floating in slow motion throughout the liquid. It is almost two decades old, so one cant judge the appearance two harshly.

S: Belgian yeast and malt. The aroma smells like a quadrupel more than a dubbel. Its already quite evident that 16 years of age has had a profound effect on this trappist ale.

T: Malty and yeasty, this old Chimay dubbel tastes like a lighter version of a quadrupel. The beer is incredibly tame and mellow, with a really enticing Belgian yeast component.

M: Low carbonation level, certainly attributed to its old age. The feel was thin to medium bodied, with alcohol flavors non-existent.

D: A really fun experience. It makes me want to buy a few cases of Chimay and tuck them away in the back of the cellar.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-07-2010

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2012 Small bottle in a 3-variety pack.  Poured into included wide-mouth glass a rich copper color with a finger of off-white head.  Aroma is sweet, fruity and yeasty.  Taste brings on some more malt, some hops, caramel, dark fruit and spices.  Great mouth-feel, smooth medium body. Tasty,
Strong abbey ale, with a deep, rich colour and firm head. Slips down easily, belying its strength. Your legs may not work as expected, after a few of these!
Rating to rate it.  I know, boring right, well it had to be done.  Least fav of the three.

33cl bottle. Copper to mahogany color with one finger off-white head, some particles in suspension. On the nose is sugary and yeasty. Aroma has spicy malts, caramel, toffee, slighty sweet fruity notes, moderately grainy, lots of yeast and a woody\earthy note. Taste is moderately sweet followed by a mild bitterness. Finish is fairly dry and sour. Alcohol can be felt. Body is medium, carbonation is sustained. Good, but not that aromatic to differ greatly from other common red beers.
pours a hazy copper with a foamy white head.fruity malt aroma intensifies smoothly in the flavour ,quite tasty but i still prefer the blue.

75cl bottle at home. Huge tan head, dark copper body. Rich aroma, somewhat tobacco-y. Not as fizzy as Blue, not as boozy. Smooth, not fizzy, almost creamy. Nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cloudy copper beer with a nice dense head. Smells fruity and malty. Tastes even more malty and bitter enough. Very balanced and smooth.
Pours hazy light copper with a tall white dense head. Fruity malt aroma. Malty spicy flavour. Some sweetness and dryness, smooth and easy. Nice

Dark orange amber with a long-lasting head and splashes of lace.  The taste begins with a tantalizing caramel malt with hints of fruit, infused through the palate with a mild balancing bittering, only to give way to the malt again in the finish.  An outstanding brew, balanced, understated in the best possible way, and a brew one can enjoy night after night.  Highly recommended.

Really good. The nose is caramel with significant dark fruit aromas. The beer is deep brown with a nicely formed beige head. The beer tastes of caramel with rasins in the background. Smooth medium plus bodied slightly sweet.

Bottle. Pours a nice dark copper color with an off white head. Aroma is of dark fruits, apricot, lots of yeast esters, some spice, breadiness and caramel. Flavor follows the nose with lots of fruit esters, apricot, dark fruits, sugary notes, spice, caramel and the breadiness. The body is medium with a silky mouth feel. Overall a pretty tasty Dubbel.
You cant go wrong with a Chimay Red. Beautiful poured into a Chimay goblet, thick, creamy head, sour/tart snappy mouthfeel...wonderful flavor explodes in the mouth. One of my faves!
Bottle at Bishop Arms, Skövde. Hazy, muddy brown with a beige head. Dark fruits, malty, caramell and some nutty aroma and similar flavour.
Bottled. Pours hazy brown with a big light brown head. Smells very caramell malty and abit nutty. Tastes caramell malty abit bitter with a nutty finish.
Big white head. Hazy brown colour. Fresh aroma with yeast. Dry, only a bit sweet. Some odd metallic flavours. Too much carbonation. Watery compared to chimay blue. A disappointment.
Nice beer, the aroma is fantastic. One good trapist beer. Worth try . Deep and dense..

Pours a ruby red color with aroma of ripe fruit.  Taste is refreshing with a touch of alcohol throughout.  A mild fruity flavor that lasts well after the swallow, lending itself to a ripened fruit aftertaste.  Overall a good beer for the style.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy caramel with a fairly thick head.  Nice aroma of caramel, dark fruits, and a bit of alcohol.  The flavor has similar notes, but is a little bit more muted.  A lot of yeast on the finish, though not in an unpleasant way.  Solid, though not quite as interesting as a lot of the other trappists.

Pours reddish murky brown with no head
Aromas of cherries, belgian yeast, maltyness
Taste of oak, cherries, hints of liqourice, dark fruits
Nice long sweet finish.

Light fruit aroma. Very unique looking - much darker than expected - nearly opaque rusty color. Sweet apple taste with a slight tartness towards the end. Barley and rye notes, but noticeably missing the Belgian yeast flavors that I was expecting...ones that are typical for other Abbey Dubbels that arent Belgian.
Para uma belga, esperava mais. O sabor é muito plano, sem profundidade. O aroma deixa um pouco a desejar e o creme não é uniforme.

Brewed in a trappist abbey a cloudy, dark almost reddish beer. Low lying, silky smooth head and a refreshing tipple! Tasting of red berries with a bitter after taste this drink feels perfectly balanced. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Probably Im mad. I had tasted a Chimay triple before I drunk an IPA and now Im having this Chimay dubbel. The interesting of this action regards the fact I didnt get enthusiastic about the triple of this same brewing (Chimay) but dubbel got me from the moment I felt the aroma on.  Summing up:  drink the dubbel but do not spend your money with the simplistic triple.

Reddish or amber dark brown. Big foam calmly settling down.

Aroma: wow! Sweet bread. Apricot. Some sweetness of caramel.

Taste: Goes down smoothly, oh my. Sweet malts are predominant. 

Full body, good balanced, not too much carbonated as common belgians.

Love it and got impressed providng the triple did not get me.
Smells of yeast and malt. Plum colour, creamy head. Cyclone of carbonation in center of glass. Tastes of plums, raisins and dough. Fabulous mouthfeel. Fantastic these corked ones.

On bottle at Trikkestallen Oslo.
Dark golden, ok foam.
Aromas of sweet dried fruits
Medium body and complexity.
Good carbonation & good balance.
Sweet taste
Enjoyable

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Delicious experience. Consumed a goblet of this amazing brew while bathing in the soothing salt streams of my mind

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2012 Poured into a wine glass. I taste lots of berries (raisins, strawberries, nuts). Served with grapes, hard white sharp cheddar and hard salami. Very enjoyable over the span of an entire afternoon.

Unfortunately I lost the notes I made for this. I do remember the taste was extremely complex, rich and enjoyable. Plums, raisins, roasted malts,  wood, caramel, cherry, sour funk, yeast, bread and orange. This beer was great.

33cl Bottle.  Appearance is dark brown color with light, beige head.  Aroma is mild with caramel, Belgian yeast, and fruit.  Taste is similar with notes of dark fruits, plum, apricot, some nuts, and a caramel malt base.  Palate is medium-bodied, smoother texture, soft carbonation, and a mild dry finish.
Pours hazy red with fruity aroma..well carbonated..  kind if a strawberry malty hints..goods stuffs

33 cl. bottle @ homa, bought @ Mitra.CLoudy brown with an off-white head. Aroma of caramel, yeast en dark fruits. Taste is likewise wirth a hint of pure chocolate. As is the case with all Trappistst: a great classic beer.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2012 from bottle. pours a slightly hazy, deep red colour with a medium sized, frothy head. the aroma is heavily malty: lots of roasted nuts and almonds, caramel and vanilla. it also has some fruity banana notes to it. the beer has an almost creamy texture and a medium body but isnt as complex as I expected it to be. quite sweet malty flavours, which are a bit weak in my opinion. however, quite decent beer!
Muy buena aunque no tanto como la azul o la blanca. Aún así una grandísima cerveza.
From the bottle. Reddish brown, cherries, raisins, other dark fruits, lovely white head, tart in taste, wonderful after-taste. Complex yet a simple joy. Loved it.

Great beer with an incredibly smooth taste and finish. Complex flavors and and amazing head.  The colour is a wonderful brown. Those Trappist monks know what they are doing. This is easily one of my top 3 beers.  Well worth the price and you MUST drink it from their special chalice/glass

Poured in my beautiful Chimay glass. Nice reddish-brown, dark amber hue, with a billowing frothy white head and brussels lacing.  Cola-like aromas, sour cherries, raisins, and dried fruits. Fresh, tart, deliciously ripe with grape juice and a hint of spice. I LOVE the aroma.  The taste is extravagant, at first sweet, then slightly drying and sour, with a very light bitterness.  Warming and pleasant, with flavors of dark cherries, plums, and a ripe juiciness.  Very carbonated, cola-like, but smooth body; brilliant finish with lingering dry fruit aftertaste.  Drank by the fire-pit on a Friday night in my backyard.  Awesome experience!

2nd May 2010Hazy chocolate brown beer. Light palate, airy. A little soft and dry. Pleasant even malt with a light touch of chocolate. Lactose sweetness and well integrated subtle orange fruit. Finishes soft and dry. Well joined up.
Fantastica birra, più fruttata e caramellata della sua sorella blu. Una delle mie birre preferite

Copper color light light fruity aroma yeast fruit light caramel. Super super beer. Lightest of chimays to me

Nice balance between malt and hops with a strong alcohol finish. Overall, this is a nicely balanced beer with complex flavoring. Id give this an A rating.
UPDATED: MAY 13, 2014 herbs, caramel, roasty, cereal, amber, clear, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, sticky, creamy, average carbonation, long finish,
Aroma of fruit, malts, and spice.  Pours dark gold with a white head.  Taste is sweet and fruity with a bitter finish.  Awesome beer.

330ml bottle. Pours a very hazy rust amber with a thin tan fluff on top. Nose is very wheaty, some raisin, plum and brown sugar. Lots of carbonation. In the mouth, plum and raisin, vine fruits, alcohol. Slightly oily, but not as much body as I was expecting. Warm fruity bitter finish.

Not as complex or floral as Chimay blue, this Belgian is nonetheless nice to drink. It's a little less complex than the lighter ones, with the maltiness a little more present than the Belgian floral yeast taste. It does have that tannic, metallic taste at points but it's not enough to keep you from enjoying it.

Bottle shared with (and courtasy of) Inbreak and ClubGonzo. Vintage 2009. Pours a very cloudy brown colour with a medium light beige head. A lovely sweet aroma of dried fruit, leather, chocolate and brown sugar. Really a round and nice smell on this. The dried fruit is also well pronounced in the flavour along wih dades, wort and sweet leather. Light bitterness in the end. Soft and slick, and a bit watery mouthfeel. Dark red-ruby color with creamy tan white head which lasts. Caramel, malts and some dark sweet fruits, probably some kind of berries. You smell and taste all the above. Live carbonation and a very smooth body. Mild bitter finish with a little alcohol. A great beer.... Truly great....

Supergod, rund smak, fyllig. Behöver lagras något år för att få rätta balansen.

Murky brown colour and smooth, white head. Aroma has some malts but its not very strong. Soft and smooth on the palate, lively carbonation. Taste is not too strong either, but it stays in your mouth for a while. I cant quite identify the flavours but it has very beer-ish feel to it. Its a decent beer but nothing spectacular.

pours a nice dark red/ ruby color, with a fissy head.   The aroma is malty, fruity, grassy.  The flavor is malt with caramel up front followed buy fruit to the rear tasting some of raisins, and other fruit i cant depict with the astringent taste to the rear contributing to some of the bitterness.  The palate is very smooth, while feeling like a heavier body.   Overall this is a very well balances beer, and would recommend
Nice red coloted with a decent home. Aroma has a sweet hint of cookie dough. The taste is very sweet and kind of cherry like. A good trappistes

Aroma is that characteristic of all Chimay beers.  Sweet bread, cookie dough, and candy sugar.  Appearance is dark brown to dark orange with a quick fading head and a great deal of particulate.  Taste is sweet and resembles that of cookie dough.  Very soft on the palate with minimal carbonation.  Overall, I would classify this as a "dessert beer".  It drinks decent on alone, but I would really like to try it with tiramisu or creme brulee. (just like the "blue" variety of Chimay)  This is a good brew and I cant wait to try it with dessert, but it is one of the most overrated beers of all time.
0,75 cl bottle. Fruity belgish trppist beer. Dark browm color, small white head, fruity, berries. In the finish is quite bitter but not too much alcohol.

750ml bottle. Aroma is fruity, specially cherry. Appearance is dark amber with a very small white head. Taste is fruity, light sour and light bitter. A very nice mouthfeel with a soft carbonation. Overall a great Trappist beer.

Cloudy murky reddish brown (lots of floaties), nice creamy off white head settles and lasts. Fruity, caramel malty, Belgian yeasty aroma. Not too cloying Belgian yeasty taste, caramel and toffee malts, sweet dark fruit, lightly spiced. Lively carbonation, medium body, lightly hopped. Mild bitter alcohol finish. Lovely. LBW (Lagerboys Be Wary)
3330ml bottle.caramel, herbs, floral. A try well made beer. I can see why the Chimay range is held in such high regard.
amber, orange, cloudy, white foam, nuts, roasty, floral, leather, medium sweetness, lightly sour, medium body, oily feel, average carbonation,
brown, cloudy, tan foam, roasty, toast, caramel, medium body, sticky, average carbonation, long finish, medium sweetness, medium bitterness,

I feel like the Chimay Red is the step child of the Chimay family. Not nearly as popular as the Blue or even the White. It often gets neglected. Its so easy to find the Chimay beers, we often take them for granted. The red is such a solid beer. Perhaps the best Abbey Dubbel that I have ever had. Notes of dates, roasted almonds, pecans, and general nuttiness. Easy to drink. Smooth. Alcohol flavor is non existant. Great beer.
Not as rich as the blue but a diverse taste that flows down well and leaves a nice subtle fruit aftertaste.

From BA: October 2007: This review is of a bottle bought in September 2007 and best before 2011, it is being drunk on my Night of the Chimay as I have all three beers and some cheese from the Abbey all purchased in Middelkerke on the Belgian coast during a resent visit.

Was it the cheese? Or was it the other Chimay beers lined up next to it, this beer was a lot better than the first review in all aspects.

It seemed richer and fuller, it looked happier too. Its aroma was wholesum and more fruity, the flavours stood out more and the overall enjoyment was a whole lot greater.

I am now really looking forward to trying the beer i have set aside for later
Pours pale yellow with little head.  Aroma is banana and hay.  Taste is sweet with a dry slightly hoppy finish.
Medium head creamy color . Liquid is copper tone. Aroma is fruity apricots. Taste is smooth also fruity. And lightly hoppy l.

La Chimay, une trappiste connue mondialement. Ce qui nest pas évident pour
les trappistes, puisque certains brassins sont vraiment à diffusion limitée.
La Chimay rouge est la première de la série, et la moins forte, tout au moins 
parmi celles du commerce, puique Chimay a aussi sa bière « confidentielle »
sous la forme dune bière diffusée à lauberge de Poteaupré près de labbaye,
et qui titre seulement à 4,8 abv.
Bref, la Première porte son nom, mais pas pour tout le monde !!! (Double jeu
de mots, maître Capello).
Cette Rouge (cest son autre nom) est néanmoins un emblème de la trappe
en Belgique, parce que chacun a son avis tranché sur cette double, qui a
ses fervents partisans et ses amateurs éclairés.
Mon exemplaire daujourdhui est à date limite en fin 2011, ce qui est mieux 
que les bières plus jeunes. Pour les double, nhésitons pas à favoriser lâge.
Dailleurs jai dégusté hier une qui était pour fin 2013 et il est évident que celle
daujourdhui est meilleure.
La couleur est un brun châtaigne un peu particulier mais qui a son charme.
La mousse est beige, pas très stable, mais elle accroche bien les parois.
Lodeur est celle dun bon vrai brassin, avec des prunes et fruits mûrs.
Le 1er goût est de prune, poire bien mûre, et céréales torréfiées (sans doute
les extraits de malt, puisque lessentiel est un orge de Champagne).
Seul petit bémol, cette première gorgée tombe un peu « raide » en finale de
bouche, je soupçonne fort le houblon Galena den être responsable, puisque
cest un bitter.
Le 2ème goût est de pruneau, girofle et noisettes grillées.
Le 3ème passe à léquilibre entre céréales, houblon et surtout la levure qui
pointe ici le bout de son nez. Cest une jolie levure, bien lisse à la bouche.
Lalcool est bien dosé et progressif, sans envahir le sujet.
La finale est soyeuse, bien agréable, avec un panel de senteurs et saveurs,
qui vous font parcourir les sous-bois, les campagnes, et les champs, sans
fausse note. 
Voilà donc une double qui tient sa place fièrement.

Appearance: Cloudy copper color with a small, creamy tan head. 
Aroma: -light to moderate- dried plums, roasted malt, raisins, brown sugar.
Taste: moderate sweet with a light bitter and astringent finish.
Palate: Medium body, lively carbonation, astringent finish. 
Overall: A bit boring.

Topped with a creamy head, it gives off a light, fruity apricot aroma produced by the fermentation. The taste perceived in the mouth is a balance confirming the fruity nuances noticed in the fragrance. Its taste, which imparts a silky sensation to the tongue, is made refreshing by a light touch of bitterness

aroma: caramel, 
appearance: brown, hazy, sparkling
head: frothy, longlasting
palate: creamy, soft carbonation

mild and smooth, pleasure to drink

Dark red appearance almost no light can pass through; good lacing; half a finger head; aroma is medium to strong hints of alcohol and grapes and plum; consistent mild sweetness with a light to medium bitter and biscuit aftertaste; creamy palate with fizzy carbonation; astringent finish

Bottle. Medium brown with foamy cream head that doesnt last that long and not much lacing. This sounds terrible, but it kind of works ok. It smells like a mixture of foot powder, grape soda, roses, and mushrooms- all kind of subtle. Not too sweet- bit of the floral and earthiness come through in the flavor- bit of spice. Moderate carbonation, a bit tingly- no cloying after taste.
From the bottle poured a hazy brown brew with a thick rick head. Aromas and flavors of malt with a touch of hops and fruityness. Medium bodied and tasty.

Bottle. Pours hazy dark reddish amber with frothy creamy head. Aroma is fresh rye bread, apple porridge, soap and metallic hints. Taste is balanced medium sweet and bitter with faint acidity. Body is creamy with good crisp carbonation. Finish is long and oily with notes of butter, toffee, chocolate and sweet licorice. Very balanced and pleasant beer.

How do I love thee? Let me count the ways.
I love thee to the depth and breadth and height
My soul can reach, when feeling out of sight
For the ends of being and ideal grace.
I love thee to the level of every days
Most quiet need, by sun and candle-light.
I love thee freely, as men strive for right.
I love thee purely, as they turn from praise.
I love thee with the passion put to use
In my old griefs, and with my childhoods faith.
I love thee with a love I seemed to lose
With my lost saints. I love thee with the breath,
Smiles, tears, of all my life; and, if God choose,
I shall but love thee better after death.
Bottle from France (Im sure there is only one shop in France :) Quite acidy, very tarte, nice for a belgian beer but I much prefer the stronger, darker less acidy ones like de struise pannepot.

Bottle @ home. Pours dark amber with a creamy offwhite head. Aroma of sweet malt, caramel, sweets, dark fruit, prunes. Taste ismalt, light yeast, sweet caramel, sweet dark fruit. Medium body, soft carbonation. 300412
This is one beer I cant quite figure out. Quite a complex taste. Slight fruity hints (I taste grapes). The color, at least to me, looks like spoiled red wine, but dont be fooled. Its a good beer.

750 mL bottle. Great nose of prunes, yeast and roasted grains. Pours a really nice mahogany color, decidedly not filtered, slightly off white head, no lacing.  Sweet, but not cloying, a nice balance of both sour fermented flavor and bitter hops, surprisingly refreshing and easy to drink for such a big beer. Nice and full bodied, creamy texture offset by medium to high carbonation. A serious beer, really love the fermented aroma and flavor it brings to the table.

750ml bottle. Careful removing the cork! Someone could lose an eye! Poured into chalice (as recommended). Thick, murky orange (Lovibond 16) with generous, cream colored head. Becomes a fairly ample lace for the duration of the beer. Rich notes of sweet, sticky, butterscotch waft up from the brew. Quite a sweet tasting beer! Not bad, although I expected more balance against the caramel taste (I can barely distinguish any hops flavour). Lively carbonation and oily mouth feel. Has a longer finish too, somewhat chalky and metallic.
Pours a deep brown color and white head. Aroma of dark fruits and yeast. Taste of dark fruits, sugar candy and yeast.  Good drinkability.
Bottled. Pours murky dark orange-amber with a short head. Raisiny aroma. Sweetish flavor. Light-medium body, good carbonation, fizzy texture, and a light, yeasty, sweet finish.

25.4 oz bottle.  Pours a coppery color with gigantic cream-colored head.  Very fizzy.  Strong aroma of apricot.  Slightly bitter flavor with strong fruity notes.  Long smooth finish.  This is pretty good.

April 21 2012. 750ml bottle poured (several times) into my Stella Artois glass. Aroma is caramelized apricots and apples. Apricot in colour at clearest areas of opaqueness around edge and thick chestnut brown solid in centre. 2" thick soapy tan head full of bubbles settles into a mirangue then slight ring of bubbles in minutes. Lacing is a desperate clinging of carbonation. First taste is caramel and apricot sweetness followed by a sour granny smith bite and alcohol metallic finish. A little harsh at first. Advantage of having large bottle is that once it sits for a minute, the flavour balances out and it tastes more familiar. Definitely unique. Palate is sticky and lingering. Poor ending to a good beer.
Gorgeous. Classic Dubbel. Malted beautifully with clean balance. So enjoyable
Everything you ever wanted from Belgian beer and maybe something more. Incredible.
UPDATED: MAY 18, 2013 330ml bottle from Bierzwerg. Dark amber colour with large lasting head. Aroma is malt, fruits, sweet. Flavour is fruits, bread, sweet, caramel, yeast.
Bottle at De Paas.  Clear red brown pour with off white head.  Light ara of fruit and caramel.  Flavour of malt, caramel and dark fruits.

Pours a hazy reddish copper with a lively frothy head which uniformly recedes. Aromas are light apricot fruits. Right of the taste is carbonated high, figs, apricots, caramel.bready, yeasty, wheaty, nice alcohol content. Good drinkability. Very tasty.

Ottima trappista che ha dalla sua un equilibrio ed una bevibilitá notevole. color marrone, al naso  note fruttate si mescolano al profumo di malto tostato. Al palato é maltata di corpo medio, giustamente gassata, con finale amarognolo molto gradevole con note tostate e di frutta (prugna). Good!
Very smooth. Chimay is always consistent. Very drinkable and you drink the whole bottle before you realize it. Ive had the blue label as well and havent been let down so far.
UPDATED: NOV 25, 2012 Opens with a nice fruity aroma and pours a deep rust red. Lots of sweet fruits and fizz in the palate, balanced with a light bitterness. Excellent.

[ASPETTO] 			
marrone castagna, velata			
[SCHIUMA]			
color crema, fine e compatta, buona presenza			
[OLFATTO]			
malto tostato, con leggeri sentori di cioccolato; un leggero fruttato e lieviti e note alcoliche			
[GUSTO]			
inzio maltato, leggermente dolce, che lascia spazio a sentori tostati che ancora  ricordano vagamente cioccolato e miele. Si passa per un fugace fruttato che si mescola subito con un amaricante finale e note alcoliche, con linsorgere di toni speziati , piccanti soprattutto nel retrogusto			
[TEXTURE]			
corpo medio, vellutata , buona carbonazione e alcohol percettibile e ben dosato.			
[COMMENTO FINALE]			
un classico e per questo spesso trattato spesso con differenza, cosinderando che occupa gli scaffali di quasi tutti i supermercati al fianco di birre più o meno industriali. Strong ale belga trappista equilibrata, di facile bevuta, con un tocco amaro che  invoglia la bevuta. direi quasi semplice, lineare e per questo ben riuscitae godibile.  potendo avere una cantina con tutti i crismi, sarebbe da lasciare riposare a lungo.. per vedere leffetto che fa!!

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2012 + mooi bruin met een soort van stroperige look.
- schuim ziet eruit als het schuim in de wasmachine, schuim is ook erg snel weg.
+/- friste citrus geur maar daarna overheerst helaas het muffe geurtje weer.

33 cl bottle.
Rated on 20090213.
Pours brown color with medium head. Aroma of yeast, caramel malts, toffee and dark fruits. Flavor of dark ripe fruits, caramel malts, toffee and mild yeast and spice notes.
UPDATED: DEC 23, 2012 Was given one for free by a Bud Light drinker so I cant complain. I still think its a little overrated.

From a 330ml bottle on 7/4/2012. Pours a cloudy light amber/light apricot with a medium head. Has a light fruity aroma with a touch of caramel. The flavour is quite sweet and malty, with lots of caramel and toffee, and a touch of dark fruit. There is a muted bitterness and a touch of warming alcohol at the end. Perhaps a touch over carbonated. Quite enjoyable but, like many other famous Belgians, over-rated.

330 ml bottle. Pours a murky red brown with nice thick head. Sour malt, spice, and a bit of caramel to the nose. Rich, spicy flavor with hints of orange peel. A bit metallic. Slightly bitter finish. A good beer.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2014 Bottle from a bar in Pisa, for the most disappointing of World Cup matches (Italy 0-1 Uruguay). Murky amber body with a beige head that fades. No lacing. Aroma of red apples, white pepper, yeast and brown sugar. Flavour of yeast, nuts and apples. Not the most complex. Medium body with a frothy, powdery mouthfeel. Lively carbonation. Quite an unusual beer with a distinct taste of apples. Overrated.

The small bottle from Morrisons. Pours murky brown with a thin white head, lots of carbonation out of the bottle. These bubbles hide the flavours first up and I think its better to let it go flat a bit first. Smells nice, like a malty Belgian ale. Taste is fruity with surprising but pleasant bitter kick in the finish, which is long. A great beer.

Definintely overrated. Great carbonation. Really fizzy for a thin headed pour. Love the corked bottle. I had the big boy. Very malty. earthy, brown, red, hazy, minimal head, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, light body, fizzy, long finish,

Dark brown beer with reddish hints. Rather opaque with "sedimented" carbonation. Frothy head and grainy yeast.
Smeel is heavy alcoholic sweetness with spies and herbs - cumin, cardamom, white pepper. Apple and green banana hints. Quite alcoholic.
The taste is watery alcoholic sweetness with a warm spicy woodiness. Well balanced and soothing.
Hazy darker rown color, foam does not stay. Fruity taste but still strong bitter taste, Strong beer, taste stays.
Very good palate with rich flavor. Aroma is a high point. Fantastic combination of fruits with a slight dry bitterness in the aftertaste.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2012 ALMOST as good as their Grande Réserve.  Première has a big-time apple and fruity kick with noticeable alcohol burn, yet not overwhelming the other flavors. Hoppier than the Grande Réserve, which makes sense since this is a dubbel and not a Belgian strong dark ale.  Overall, extraordinary complexity of flavor.  I gave this and the Grande Réserve to a wine aficionado, and he was impressed, saying they were by far the best beers hes ever sampled.  SUMMER SAMPLE: Okay, not *quite* the mind-blowing beer I remember as a relative Belgian newb.  It wouldnt be fair to rate this ahead of, say, the amazing Rochefort quad.  Still, one of the best Ive ever had of any style.

Light malt and yeasty aroma.  Dark copper color.  Taste is a bit thin, malty with sour grape.  Finish is a bit breadth.  Palate is interesting but not overly complex.  I have been spoiled with the Chimay Blue, so this, while decent, does not compare.
Bottle thanks to mar, Pour is copper..Nose is bready,floral, spice, wet wood,grass, grape..palate is light with spice

AROMA: fruity, woody
APPEARANCE: red, brown, clear, frothy,
TASTE: light sweetness, medium bitterness
PALATE: full body, soft and smooth feel, bitter, long finish
OVERALL: full-bodied smooth-tasting perfectly-balanced trappist.

From notes: Poured hazy nut brown, with a 1-finger off-white head and some bubbling along the glass.  Funky, earthy yeast aroma mixed with a sour note, possibly cherry.  Medium-thick, full-bodied with a slight fizziness.  Flavor was mild, but complex.  Some nutty flavors mixed with tart sour cherry and earthy yeast.  Long finish with some of the cherry showing, but the yeast is more notable.

33cl bottle. Pours a white shallow head. Sweet balanced malty aroma. Sugary, hoppy and yeasty flavour. Not as much out-of-the-box flavours as chimay blue, i.e chocolate. But still, this is quality from top to toe. Duce point!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a very hazy copper brown with a fizzy tan head that quickly dissipates. Smell is very faint with fruits and yeast. Taste is light and complex with sweet tropical fruits, grape, yeast, mellow spices, and subtle dry hops. Carbonation tickles the tongue. Texture is smooth. Some warming from the alcohol. This one is pretty light but hold a lot of complexity to it. Well balanced and well crafted for a very enjoyable experience.

From notes.  First reviewed 11/9/2011.  Poured from a 330 mL bottle into a Chimay chalice at Firkin.

The pour is a caramel brown color with a general opaque nature and a medium sized tan head.

Mostly smooth caramel malt in the nose, with some soft orchard and dark fruits, and some Belgian spice.

The taste flows well from the nose. Caramel malt, cherry, plum, a bit of raisin and red grape notes go along with a nuanced Belgian spice. The finish is still sweet, but not as much as the start of the sip. 

The body is on the light side of medium for the style. It is creamy, but also a bit fizzy. Clean and smooth,

There is a good reason Chimay beers have been around forever. They are delicious.

Un profumino di malto leggero con un elegante effusione di albicocche e in minima parte di pesca. Il gusto è fruttato e leggermente amaro nel finale. Al palato è vellutata. Non è filtrata ne pastorizza, recita la descrizione commerciale. Ciò sembra essere confermato dal deposito di sedimenti in fondo alla bottiglia. Tipo il limo del nilo. Potresti coltivarci sopra qualcosa.
Its a foamy hazy reddish-copper pour. Aromas caramel, honey, fruit. Taste is gentle sweetness with background spice. 7% well hidden.
Delicious lighter version of the blue. Great caramel and light sugary notes. Lots of carbonation, delicious!

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2012 Net te koud ingeschonken, kraag snel weg. Fris zoet, abrikoos, beetje hooi aroma. Redelijk wat koolzuur. Smaak is licht koffie, hazelnoot (en groentebouillon?!), doch geen heftige body, eerder waterig. Nasmaak is een wat zoet-bitter. Niet geheel overtuigend, bier groeit niet tijdens drinken. Wellicht nog eens proberen.

Brown color with large cream colored head rests atop. Fair amount of lace trails. Fruity yeast scents, some sweetness. The taste is dominated by various fruit flavors, some malty sweetness. Pinch of hops, along with a drop of alcohol flavor.

This beer is unreal. A- Amazing hazy, copper red. Thin white head, leaves a great ring around the glass. S- oranges, yeast, raisins, fruit T- caramel, figs, dark fruits. Wow, cant get enough of this. M- light and smooth and creamy. A sweetness that lasts on the palate. O- Unbelieveable. Not as big as the Blue, but amazing in its own way. Thought it would be heavier, but the flavor is all there. This is legendary.

Characterized by a silky taste on the tongue and a slight touch of bitterness toasted the end.

Pours red with a medium foam head.
Nose: a bit of reduction, very yeasty and malty. Nice first impression, then quickly disappears because of a thin body, lack of persistence for a trappist beer!
Basic hopping, short aftertaste. Far from the St Bernardus Range !

Cloudy dark amber with lasting creamy beige head. Lovely mouthfeel, very silky texture, nice body. Taste is some raisins and overripe fruit, caramel malts, yeast. Medium sweet with a light bitter after taste.
This is like the rough and ready younger brother to the Blue.  The notes arent as refined and the spices come through a bit more bold.
Pours amber with a medim head with some decent retention and lacing. Malt and spice with light hop nose. Flavor is the caramel malt and some fruit/ golden raisin and apricot. Very drinkable.

a: hazy amberish brown, nice 1/2" foamy head with fair retention

m&d: medium mouth feel, finished the 750 ml with no problems amd a slight buzz.
UPDATED: JAN 10, 2015 slight malty aroma. dark red in color with a huge frothy head. taste is of darker caramel malts, faint cherry note. good body, smooth finish.
Dark amber colour. Caramel aroma. Taste is spicy, caramel toffee and yeast and slightly sweet. Decent beer.

My ollady turned me on to this beer. I like it so much I have brewed two batches in an atempt to duplicate it. Love the fruitiness of the belgian yeasts. Not at all a hoppy beer. At $12 a bottle, not a session beer.

Hazy reddish brown. Yeasty-spicy-sweet aroma. Taste is crisp maltiness with powerful caramel and yeast. Some spice and fruit in the background, hops in the finish along with some dryness. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, prickly carbonation.

Bottle 330ml 

Pouring: Jumps out of the bottle. White foaming head (brown). Big sized bubbles. low lacing. Aromas of malt. Taste of malt, sligth bitterness from the hops. Not bad, nice balance. A little watery for me, but refreshing.
Pours a slightly thick caramel color with nice sediment. Dried apples and caramel on the nose. More of the same on the palate with full mouthfeel and smooth finish. Very enjoyable beer.
Transfering data from personal beer file. I drank this beer a long time ago. Ill update this rating if I have the chance to drink it again.

Bottles pours a deep hazy amber red. 2 finger off white head that dissipates rather quickly. Fruity yeast aromas is apparent - think citrus and apricots. Moderate carbonation. Initially bitter, almost harsh but subsequent malt sweetness spreads. Tastes of dark fruits like grapes and berries with some zest. Full bodied with a mildly sweet, clean finish. Nice balance of fruity sweetness and bitter hops.
Bottle. Pours dark amber with with a substantial head. Fruity yeast aroma. Flavour is candy fruitbalanced with hop bitterness. Clean finish. A quality brew.

Foam one finger finger head. Hazy brown color mild spice apricot  nose. Sour middle with a mild bitter start. Clean finish. Hints of fruitiness and highly carbonated. Has a zesty  tantalizing sensation on your tongue. A true joy to be savored. Well balanced brew.
Wow, yeah, thats good. Easy-on-the nose and really funny in the throat. Perfect for a thought.

Pours dark amber with a huge head. Aroma of yeast, fruit and hops. Medium bodied with a pretty smooth palate, but a good acidic bite at the end of it.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

330 ml bottle. Pours an orangeish pale brown with a thin white head. Smells of fieldberries. Tastes very sweet, reminiscent of fruits and brown sugar. Hint of bitterness in the finish. Body is average. Good abbaye, but Ive definitely had better.
Zoete geur van pruim, vijg en wat banaan; smaak combineert zoet, zuur en bitter. Prikkelend op de tong, met zachte nasmaak waarin de vijg terugkomt. Een aanrader bij kaas.
This taste is quite strong. The taste is more bitter than sweet. It has a subtile fruity taste. The most positive thing of the beer is the appearance: dark red and clear.

Big head. Full nose, scents of citrus, wheat and hops. Tastes a little bitter, wheaty, citrus, and hop taste in there. Great deep amber color. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2014 Dark caramel brown, slightly hazy with rich creamy beige-colored foam head. Yeasty nose. Body is medium, carbon high. Texture is thick making lace on glass. Taste seems to be bitter. Palate consist of toasted nuts, stone fruits, roated malts, dried apricots, bread dough, a slight woody tones. Bitter finish. 33cl bottle - pours opaque brown with copious tan head and decent lacing.  Nose is yeast, pilsner-like and barley.  Aroma is alcohol, light hops and caramel malts.  Taste is sweet and ends a bit bitter.  Medium body and thin texture.  Again, I am disappointed in another Chimay.  Its a good beer, but I dont see how it has such high ratings.

Inviting aroma, notes of pear and apricot. Similar yeasty smells as a home brewed wort. Head, bubbles, and carbonation at a medium level. Not as intense as 7%ABV would suggest, medium body with a lengthy, slightly bitter aftertaste. Round and creamy texture with a tongue coating velvet feeling. Pulling sweet, bitter, roasted and malty flavors. Complex, rich, and well balanced.

Appreciated.

(bottle).  A Belgians go, this is a standard.  A solid staple unfortunately, it does not set the high bar for the Dubel style.  Nice head and lacing. Aroma is a traditional pleasant malt.  Flavor is fruity with Belgian malt and yeast 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This Belgian pilsner  poors beautifully with a nice dark coppery brown color and the perfect white frothy head you expect from any Chimay. It has a nutty/ frutty aroma and a distinctive flavor.
Soda-like head, hazy amber color. Smell is citrus, caramel, and bready toast. Taste is bready and slightly fruity. Feels like drinking champagne.
caramel, spruce, basement aromas, cough drop, woody, brown, cloudy, tan foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, umami, full body, slick feel, soft carbonation, long finish,

Bottle at home. Pours a deep copper colour, with a finger of thick foamy head. Aroma of dark fruits, plums etc with malts, breadiness. Taste is brilliant, really rich with sweet dark fruits, good malty backbone, brown sugar, a hint of hop spice too. A little fizzy, nice fairly bitter aftertaste stops it from becoming cloying. Medium body, nice bit of alcohol warming as well. Great, a nice accessible classic.

January 9, 2012;7% abv, 750 mL bottle, BBD: 2015: refrigerated, not at home... rock glasses.

The nose is most sweet bready malts with some floral hops. Not nearly as impressive as the aroma of white. Pours a deep hazy copper with a thick head with mild visible carbonation. Creamy lacing on the glass. Sweet bready malts, something along the lines of a biscuit with honey. Some mineral water flavors in the aftertaste. My description doesnt fit the complexity. Very light hops, with slight bitterness. Astringent and spicy alcoholic finish. Surprisingly thin and light  considering my impression from the head and lacing. Very good, still have one more.

Dark coppery brown with small biege disappearing head . Rich malty yeasty aroma that carries through to the taste which then becomes slightly bitter towards the end .Carbonation was quite low .Body was thinner than I expected .Im surprised it scores quite so highly .Maybe it is just not my style  .
Its a foamy hazy reddish-copper pour.  Aromas caramel, honey, fruit.  Taste is gentle sweetness with background spice.  7% well hidden.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2012 750ml bottle pours light brown with a big off-white head. Very nice aroma of the belgian yeast, some roasted malt, fruit, a little hops, and a touch of alcohol. The taste is very nice. It includes belgian yeast, roasted malt, some fruit, and a touch of hops.
Aroma dolce e fruttato. Gusto morbido e ricco. Corpo non eccessivo. Ha dalla sua il costo abbordabilissimo e la facilità di reperimento.
Poured a very hazy dark copper with a creamy off-white head. Aroma was apricot, some raisin or dates and bit acidic. Taste is bread, fruits, and acidic as well. Very fizzy mouthfeel.
Aroma is a sweet caramel malt. Taste has a strong sweetness with hints of caramel chocolate. Overall pretty good, but not extraordinary.

33 cl. bottle.  Cloudy red/brown coulor with a big off-white head, that slowly fades to a fat cap. Aroma is those complex Belgian yeasts, brown sugar, bread, light pepper, and light apricots and banana.  Sweet taste with notes of bread, malts, sweet fruits and a light bitterness in the finish. Medium to full body, Nice and creamy texture. Long lasting finish. An excellent dubbel - enjoyed this one.

Bottle (330ml):
There is a strong smell of dried fruits from this beer, dark summery fruit and berries in particular along with a touch of alcohol and grain owing to the strong alcohol content. There is also a strong malt aroma and a faint touch of caramel on the nose along with some good spicy notes right at the end.

Dark, orangey brown colour when poured and forms a thick looking, three-finger sized head that is off-white and foamy. The head roughly halves in size over the course of about a minute then holds at around a finger width tall for the remainder of the drinks life.

Sweet tasting with a lot of dried fruit to begin with in the taste and perhaps a bit of apple too. There is a lot of brown sugar like flavouring and a little bit of the roasted malts from the nose as well along with touches of alcohol. Its is a pretty solid effort from this beer.

Huge carbonation in this beer, a lot more than I had been expecting but that is not to say it was overly carbonated because it seemed to work for this particular beer. It was pretty smooth, with a medium body and great drink-ability; overall an nice beer on the palate.

A very good beer overall and one that I really enjoyed, it has most things going for it and not a lot holding it back. It may not be as good as Chimay Bleue but it was still a very good beer indeed.

1001 Beers Blog: htp://abarwithnoname.wordpress.com
Bottle - very big thick head, dark amber color, sweet malty aroma, sweet malty flavor with that Belgian yeast kick, almost a little bit of a chocolate flavor in there as well - very good beer

New Years. Poured into goblet. Dark ruby red, fizzy carbonation keeps thin layer of foam present on top.  Aroma is spicy yeast, caramel, dried dark fruit.  Sweet caramel start, with plum, then gingerbread spice in the middle, and hint of coffee bitterness in the finish.  Lighter body than expected. Deceptively sessionable.

Pours a murky amber - brown. The aroma is fruit and yeast - raisin, peach, and apple. Quite light bodied, perfect creamy carbonation, very fruity, slightly bitter finish, very drinkable. No where near the complexity of the Blue or White, but a delicious and classic beer. A great trappist dubbel.

Pours a cloudy medium-brown with a foamy off-white head. Aroma is raisin, cherry, apricot, and mildly yeasty. Taste is not as sweet as expected, given the frutiness of the aroma; its actually somewhat bitter and alcoholy. Palate is creamy and rich, with a bitter finish. Not my fave double.
750 ml bottle.  Pours deep browny red in colour, lots of creamy fluffy offwhite head.  Tonnes of lacing.  Big sweet, raisiny sweet aroma and taste,  \some bitterness.  Quite good!

33cl bottle. Poured a brown beer with frothy, tan and quickly diminishing head. Aroma is toasty, alcoholic and yeasty. Flavour has dry fruits notes, sweet, candi sugar with a moderate alcoholic and yeasty final. Carbonation is medium. Texture is oily. Body is high.

bottle. pours cloudy red with a small tan coloured head. plum and biscuits in the nose and pleasant bitterness in the mouth. full body, light carbonation, long aftertaste and very balanced. great beer.
Dark reddish color with very good head. Fruity aroma. Caramel malty flavor.
Aroma is delicious! Fruity apricot aroma with the creamy density of the head similar to champaign bubbles. Very smooth and fruity taste with just a slight bitterness and alcohol kick.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2011 pours nice dark mahogany with a tanned head. aroma of dark fruits, caramel and brown sugar. taste is rich and sweet. there are dark fruits, cloves, and floral spice. there is a nice silky texture, with just the right amount of carbonation. quite a strange mineral quality in the finish, and its not as deep/complex as some, but its still really good.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2012 0,33l bottle from Belgium. Hazy light brown color with frothy beige head. Interesting cheese, barley, fruits and alcohol aroma. Its a bit smoky. Medium bitter-sweet taste. Medium body with creamy texture and average carbonation. Bitter-sweet fruity finish. Its a wonderful beer. Unique aroma and taste. Very good choise.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2011 cream coloured frothy head and cloudy yellow brown colour. Esters and malted roast and cream or yeast notes as well as some dark prune and brown sugar like notes. the flavours are about balance between richness, alcohol and malts as well as a very carbonated and somewhat hoppy note. very nice.

Dark, reddish colour, quite hazy. Thick, creamy head. Aroma vinous, fruity and yeasty: dandelion, liquorice, slight hints of peach. Fairly bitter in taste, full bodied and rich, I certainly noticed the astringency mentioned in the brewers description which makes this a beer to enjoy slowly.
Deep red/brown color. Moderate frothy head. The nose is quite malty, with bitter sweet notes. The taste is suprisingly dry, somewhat bitter. Mouthfeel is pleasant, not too aggressive. OK.

Poured a hazy copper color.  Full Frothy head.  Yeasty flavors on the nose with some hops and slight fruit.  Med light bitter and light sweetness.  Finishes on the drier side.  This abbey dubbel is more bitter than most, but thats not a bad thing.  Not bad stuff.  The blue is by far the best chimay.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 Royale kraag die snel verdwijnt. Bitterzoete vlakke smaak, weinig body. Ik ben nooit een fan van chimay geweest maar ik dacht geef het nog een kans. Helaas, not my cup of tea euhhhh bier.

Re-rate: ABT bier van de maand.

Van de tap @ de klep.  Roodbruine kleur en een dichte, vaste kraag. Ruikt wat moutig en smaakt idem met wat vage fruittonen. Vrij zoet.  Smaakt me beter als uit de fles.

Pours dark and hazy with a large, stable head. Aroma is malt and spices, caramel and a hint of spruce. Texture is a bit thin for such a heavy beer.  Taste is faintly bubblegum, malty and spicy, with a warm and slightly bitter palate.

Deep red copper with a creamy off-white head that slips away pretty quickly.  Instantly the aroma of hops, spice and fruit fill your nostrils.  Sweet from the fruit and a pinch or caramel, bitter, wheat, and a silky finish coats your mouth.  Slight flickering of spice, I think clove and I picked up apples and raisins at some point.

Super stuff !

Original rating : april 2005 
Head: thick, white 
Colour: ruby/brown 
Smell: fruity, malts, bit grainy, fairly sweet 
Taste: starts is malty but not as sweet as i tought , some yeasty and hopy biterness, allong with some irony flavours in the end , not bad
33cl bottle. Deep red brown with nice cream head. Sweet fruit on the nose. Candy sugar on the tongue with a delicious hap bitterness. Dried raisiny fruit. This was delicious.

Pours a murky light brown, with a persistent light tan head. Aroma is spicy and tangy, like slightly sour milk. Taste is burnt caramel with a big hit of malty sweetness, toast and nuts. Nice carbonation, medium bodied and nice drinking.
Bottle. (gusher) pours dark red with white head. Aroma of malts, dark fruits, some caramel. Taste is sweet some bitterness. Ok

Pours a nice red body, coming up to a thick head. Aromas are yeasty and spicy, light overall however. Flavors of dried citrus and dark fruits coat the taste buds in a mellow smooth taste. Undertones of light hops and brown sugar offer a nice twist of tastings. Drinkable stuff here.
bottle from el corte ingles, lisbon. Large dense head. Brown redish color. Medium sweetness. High caramel and malt aroma.

Mousse généreuse et pétillante qui reste assez longtemps pour se faire apprécier.   Belle robe rouge brun opaque.  
Odeur :  Une odeur complexe dépice et de caramel qui sessoufle un oeu vite.
Piquant sur la langue (Co2, pas tabasco!), goût complexe dépice (disons coriandre et clou de girofle. ;) ), amertume costaude (sans être dans le territoire dune IPA), caramel discret et peut-être un peu de vanille (je cite les experts ;) ).  Bref, il sen passe des choses en bouche!

Dark clear ruby beer, firm white head. Aroma of malts, fruits, yeast tones and light candy sugar and caramel. Flavour light sweet, malts, fruity, light candy sugar with fresh hops shining through. Finish bit sweet with a nice bitterness.
(From 75cL bottle @ home)

Bottle:
Another one of the Chimay Cultus I have had many times in the past.
Recently re-drunk this one and after having some of the finest beers in the world, this one still taste damn good.
A nice ruby warm beer, which is maybe even better than all those so called herfst bock beers, yes, definitely better.
A glass of this beer with a good autumn/winter meal makes you enjoy life even more.
This brew still kicks ass!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Purchased at West Lakeview Liquors in Chicago, IL as part of a Chimay package w/ a glass, enjoyed while watching week 10 NFL football.  Appearance a very cloudy, murky brown/red with a rich off white head.  Aroma very nice, fruity, very slightly sweet, not really too much of an aroma.  Taste is pretty good, smooth, Belgian yeast presence, fruity (apricot), Ive had the white and I really enjoy it, but with this red Im not as impressed.  Its good, but not great.

33cl bottle. Dark reddish or dark amber with a good head also a bit red. Nose : Fruity ; mostly cherry. Delicate bread malts. Sip : the beer still foams in the throat. Smooth. Caramel malty. Delicate fruit notes are marked by sour yeast that this beer develops after couple of sips. Good that the sourness isnt like in the cider. The aromatic hops are easily selected in mouth which makes it refreshing. Rare for a dark beer.  Normally I always avoid the red Chimay to jump into blue or golden but I must say that I will have some dilemmas now while choosing between golden and red.

not sure really.  big gusher, lost quite a bit before it calmed down enough to get in the glass! aroma of malt and deep red fruitiness,  some sweetness too.  big foamy head! tastes spicy and fruity.  
save the rest for a proper bottle

Subdued aroma eighths advertised peach/apricot notes. Hazy copper orange withwith persistent offshore film. Taste is lightly sweet with fruity esters predominant. Nice balance with the hop bitterness. Fairly well dried out with crispy carbonation keeps palate fresh. Nice bready malt in the finish.
330ml bottle, poured into Palm glass. Two finger tanned head. Dark ruby colour. Strong fruity aroma. Tasted cherries, chocolate and mousse au chocolat. So smooth, great texture. Top beer.

PSSSSSSSH! Wow, a bit too carbonated, this one! A gusher, and I have to clean my living room table before continuing the rating. The gushing caused the dark amber brownish body to end up very hazy, almost cloudy. The medium-sized off-white head is quite long-lived, and laces the glass very well. A bit faint, moderate sweet malty aroma with noticeable hoppy and yeasty notes. I get caramel, yeast, fruit, honey and spices. Medium sweet and light to medium bitter taste with a long-lasting yeasty dry finish. Flavours are yeast, fruits, honey, spices, caramel and alcohol. Good mouthfeel, but it actually feels a bit thinner that Id expected from an abbey dubbel. Still a very nice beer, may I have another, please? 
[33 cl bottle, from Vinmonopolet Storo, Oslo]

bottle....33 cl..It pours clear red brown with a big fluffy tan head.... the aroma is sweet, malty, nice good fruitiness..... the flavor is roasted malts, sweet, dark fruits, caramel and some alcohol not as much at Chimay Blue....... some belgian yeast finish....

I kept this magnum bottle at room temperature because I wanted to drink the beer at a slightly higher temperature  expecting a deeper and more complex taste. There is a lot of pressure when I remove the cork, the beer tries to find its way out immediatly.

Colour: Chimay Première leaves a reddish brown beer in the glass, slightly hazy with not much carbonation. The creamy head is thick and beige. It leaves a nice lacing on the glass when dissapearing very slowly.

Aroma: very sweet smell with a malty undertone and a spicy touch of pepper. A very inviting and intense smell.

Taste: Chimay Première is a very drinkable beer with an ABV of only 7%. At first, the taste seems relatively simple, dominated by malts and hop bitterness. When taking a few more sips however, the beer becomes complex of taste and very well balanced with a warming alcohol presence. The full body is combined with a fresh crispness. The mouthfeel is a bit like syrup and sticky. The dry finish makes you longing for more instantly.

Try this beer with a beef stew  why not use it IN the beef stew. Chimay Première will also go well with any grilled meat dish. And why not drink it as dessert ? Beats a cappucino !
Bottle - Pours reddish brown with a frothy off white head.  Nice mix of spice and fruit in the aroma.  Smooth mouth feel. The alcohol comes through nicely in the taste.
Its a good beer, but I love the triple (blanche) so much that Ill usually choose it over the chimay red.  Not to say that this isnt a great beer... strong taste of alcohol, light florals.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2011 Aroma: Dark malt, Belgian yeast is very pungent.

Appearance: Opaque brown with a pillow style head and carbonation action in the goblet.

Taste: Rich. Light caramel, light bitterness, mostly just a smooth belgian ale with a semi-dry finish.

Palate: Thick but smooth.  The quality is clear from the first sip.

Overall: Incredible beer.  Its nearly impossible to pick a favorite Chimay.  All three are killer.

Dark brown, light, big bubble head that sticks well. Medium-dark reddish brown. Tons of spice in the aroma, along with a good dose of Trappist funk. Effervescence is high, but doesnt bite too hard--actually quite soft. Good dryness to it. A bit of metal and fruit rind in the flavor.

Brown with only a little head which only lasted for a short time. Probably the bottle was not chilled enough. intensive smell of banana, citrus and other fruits. tastes quite the same. some spicy flavours in there, too. full body and soft carbonization. long lasting taste of yeast and a little bitterness can be found at the end. very good!

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2012 Tasted from bottle into tulip glass. Poured a beautiful copper color with some yeast haze and frothy, dense, lasting off-white foam, some Belgian lace. Aromas of sweet bread, caramelized brown sugar, rising dough, some plum, raisins and dried cherries, no late hops. Flavors of rich, diverse malts: bread, toast, biscuits, toffee, more dark stone fruits, slight clove balanced by low earthy hops bitterness. Medium body with well-rounded mouthfeel, lasting sweetness and fruitiness in the finish. High carbonation, tiny bubbles from active bottle fermentation. Delicious in every way. An absolute masterpiece.
Bottle from a sample pack. Sweet and fruity with a light tartness. grows more complex as it warms up. A touch of bitterness at the end.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2014 Pours a nice amber color with a quickly dissipating head. Aroma is of hay barnyard, boozy fruit, citrus, cheese funk, spice and herbs, very light and crisp. Tastes of hay and grain, cherries, fig, plum skin, black pepper, spicy saison yeast, horse blanket, bready, grape must and golden raisin. Very complex beer with easy to pick out notes. Very layered and very delicious.

A white nice head, which didnt last that long. Darkbrown, little redish colour. Some sweetness in the smell and some malt. Little fruit and alcohol in aroma. Soft, round and creamy feeling in the mouth. Little cake or tart in the taste and some bready malt.

750ml corktop bottle from the LCBO. Pours a beautiful dark brown/red with a thick beige head with a tint of red. Aroma is caramel and malt. Slightly spicy. Taste is somewhat sweet with Belgian yeast, caramel and malt. Some spices. bread like flavour with some toffee. 
Nothing in the flavour stands out as being really bold. This is a solid well rounded and balanced beer.
Bottle. Dark brown with a minimal head.  Berries and the typical belgian trappist taste. Not Bad.

Very nice and balanced. Dark amber with a medium, frothy, tan-colored head. The aroma suggests notes of fruit cake, malts, caramel, and a bit of yeasty citrus. The taste is sweet and bitter, but not overdone either way. The mouthfeel is solid and assertive, with vigorous carbonation and a medium body. Very, very nice.
pours a cloudy brown with thick foamy head.  fruity aroma, dark fruits, like figs.  a bit of brown sugar in the taste.  robust flavor.  excellent
Dark fruit and a hint of alcohol in the aroma.  The flavor is fruity, possibly raspberry/strawberry and malty.  Not quite at the top but very solid and a good ale either way.

A: The taste has ripened fruit, fig, yeast and some caramel malts
A:  Pours a murky ruby brown with a thin bubbly tan head.  The carbonation is very lively upon the pour.
T:  The taste is a smooth blend of the same aromas; dark ripe fruit, caramel malt and a little spice.
P:  Decent lively carbonation, but smooth
O:  I have had this offering before, but just now rating.  Very nice and almost at any respectable bottle shop.  Heck I found this down in Australia where the variety is particulary poor in the area Im in.  Just an overall good beer.

Location: 33 ml bottle from Costco in Richmond, 9/24/11


Aroma: The nose is fairly sweet, with caramel malts, some dark fruits, Belgian yeast, and spice

Appearance: The pour is a cloudy dark orange-brown with a thick and creamy, lasting, lacy beige crown

Flavor: The taste is medium sweet, with a Belgian yeast, roasted caramel malts, and some fruity notes

Palate: The body is medium-full with a creamy and chewy mouthfeel, and soft-to-average carbonation

Overall Impression: 
Its fairly surprising to see that I got all the way to rating 1885 before entering one for Chimay Red, but somehow I managed.  I like this beer, but I dont really tend to order/buy it very often for some reason, but when I walked into Costco and saw this 3 pack (Red, White, and Blue) + a glass offering for like $12 I couldnt resist.  Thats a heck of a deal!  So, I, of course, enjoyed this one in my new Chimay glass.  This one is so easy to find, that it probably doesnt the respect it deserves, but it is a really good beer.  I wont hold its accessability against it, if anything, that should be a plus, becuase they make so much of it and they still make it so well.  It is about time that I got around to inputing a rating for this one, and I look forward to getting new/updated versions of the other two up here soon.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2011 33ml, wine glass. Audibly fizzy. 
Cloudy, copper brown. Beige head diminishing to thin, patchy.  Small bubbles.
Sweet, fruity smell, not unlike a wine.
Sweet malts, spicy aftertaste, light bitterness with time.
Palate thin, overcarbonated.
Overall not much depth and carbonation reduces pleasantness.

This brew poured up a murky mahogany colored body with an enormous frothy head with amazing retention and lacing effects. Aromas of sweet malts, spices, and peppers. Flavors of the same along with cloves, dark fruits (dates and plums), and warm hints of chocolate. Medium-bodied with a dry finish and lingering aftertastes of sweet malts and spices. This brew improves as it warms after pouring.

33cl bottle with red label.
small beige foam, light and quickly disappearing, over an hazy, copper brown liquid.
aroma: dried plums, raspberry and yeasts.
taste sweet with some fruity tartness in the final. good alcohol feeling with the right carbonation to sustain it. body is lighter than expected

33cl Bottle. Lovely aroma of fruit, raisins and caramel. Pours a medium off white head which fades quickly, dark red in colour. Flavour is initially sweet with a slightly acidic after taste which stays in the mouth for a good while. Texture is smooth and creamy.

Bottle from Csakajosor.hu. Poured murky, dark burgundy-brown color and a beige lively foam that eventually became a lacing one. Plum, caramel, cinnamon, mints, cellar, hops in the aroma. Not as dense as I expected, with pretty high carbonation. Sweet taste, which becomes even sweeter in the aftertaste. Good one.

pours a copper brownish red with a nice off white head that laces nicely. the nose is of sweet summer fruit, plums, apricot, light malts and grains. A very balanced beer that is a good option to bring to dinner at a non craft fans house.

Deep reddish brown pour with a thick creamy head. Smooth malty taste creamy body, slightly sweet with hints of clove, caramel and fruit. Aroma is a little oxidized, a little sweet and some earthy hop notes. Classy beer.

I cant write anything about Chimay that the previous 2000 reviewers havent already said.  Great beer, but IMO, its worth the extra couple of bucks to buy the blue or white instead of the red.  With that said, the red is still world class.

Bottle looks really simple but really good. Beer in the glass light brown, small head. Spicy-roasty aroma. Starts mild, almost a bit washy. Gets more and more moldy-malty. Finish a bit more warming, but still milder than exspected. I exspected more and I am a bit disappointed.

Bottle from some club in Chicago. Pours hazy dark brown with small tan head. Aromas of raisins, dark caramel, brown sugar, and yeast. Flavors of belgain yeast, caramel, dark fruits, and dark bready malts. Nice body and carbonation.

(bottle 6/26/10). Cloudy brown/copper color. Medium off white head. Moderate fruity raisin aroma, with light spicy belgian yeast character. Flavor of the same. Avg duration. Light dry, light alcohol finish. Thin/fizzy texture. Moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Appearance: Pours a cloudy brownish-orange with a head that almost instantly disappears. Looks a little dead.

Aroma: Plum, raisins, molasses and soy sauce.

Taste: Plum and figs, dark musty fruit, light molasses. Some light clove and hops toward the end.

Palate: Moderately high carbonation, a little fizzy (despite the dead look), medium body with a strange finish.

Overall: Decent Dubbel that, in my opinion, does not live up to its Trappist reputation. Still pretty tasty though.

11.2oz bottle from the state store 
Appearance: Pours hazy dark amber with a big frothy white head and good lacing 
Aroma: Malts, Belgian yeast and sweet 
Taste: Malty, dark fruit, spices and bitter finish 
Nice
Pours hazy brown with a medium head. Light aroma is malts and dark fruits. Flavor is sweet malts, fruits and some alcohol. Stingy carbonation. Great.
Cloudy reddish brown with a small pale head. Aroma is of caramel, dark fruits. Medium palate, flavours of brown sugar, citrus, a little nuttiness, and a bitter finish.

Browish red body, tiny and bubbly head. Caramel, raisins, coriander seeds and early. Sweet body that sticks to the mouth, even with the watery texture. Long aftertaste and alcohol is well hidden. This is the opposite of refreshing and although well brewed I never got to like it really. Cheap. (33cl bottle, 1,60 EUR)

Hazy light brown color with a pillowy head that hangs around for a bit. The flavor features big, full malt, a hint of hops to cut through the sweetness, and some apricot in the finish. Starts creamy and ends dry. Very interesting sensation. As it warms, Im getting butterscotch and some pepper.

Overall, a sensational beer. Big flavors, great texture, complex, and balanced.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2012 330ml bottle. Pours a brown colour with a thick, light tan head. Aroma of Belgian candi sugar, caramel, treacle, yeast and light black pepper. Nice flavour of Belgian candy sugar, treacle, caramel and yeast again. Little fruitiness with blueberry and raisin notes. Foamy mouth-feel and a spicy, peppery linger. Nice. Also had this on draught at Delirium Monasterium. Pours a dark red colour with a fair beige head. Aroma of biscuity malt, candy sugar and alcohol. Similar flavours with mild bitterness. Moderate carbonation and a foamy mouth-feel. Alcohol is well balanced.

Bière de couleur rouge cuivrée, avec un de ces cols quil faut laisser le temps quil se dissipe un peu avant de finir de la verser. Elle contient des odeurs évidentes de levure et dalcool accompagnées de prunes séchées. La palette de goût ressemble énormément aux odeurs, en plus du pain grillé avec une belle amertume, le tout bien équilibré.

fruits, malt, bronze color, fizzy, medium body, 
Bottled. Little bit different of the blue one. More fruits, more sugar. Easier but a bit less complex. But whatever, a very good beer.

First experience of Chimay beer - a few months ago. Ill let the description say it all as Im not good with beer descriptions! A wonderful tasting beer, apricot aroma, copper with a white head.  Simply superb.
user_location: Chapel en le Frith, Derbyshire, ENGLAND

text:
Pours a reddish amber, white foamy head.
Spicy aroma, coriander, black pepper, wild cheesy yeast aroma.
Crisp sweetness.
Full bodied, oily, lively carbonation, long chewy finish.
While not my favorite Dubbel, this is still a very solid beer.  A wonderful aroma is the highlight of this beer.  (more detail to come!)
Brown color, white head. Smell caramel, yeast and a little bit spicy. Decent taste, good full carbo and medium to full body.
Bottle @ taste 10 cl. Dark brown with a reddish tint with a medium off white head. Aroma of dark fruit, malt and yeast. The taste is slightly fruity with notes of banana

This is the first of the 3 Chimays that I want to try!  Went for the cheapest first!  Pours a nice reddish brown color.  Off white medium sized head.  Has a nice malty aroma.  Very good malty character with some brown sugar and caramel.  Very good for a dubbel.  Wouldnt say this is my favorite style but I am thoroughly enjoying this beer.

Opálos rozsdabarna, szépnek nem mondanám. A hab is teljesen elkopik.
Élesztős kukoricás illat enyhe zöldséges felhanggal. Erősen szénsavas. Édes alkoholos test. Pörkölt maláta íz enyhe komlózás miatt nem keserű.
Mint legtöbbször a trapisták, nekem túl édes.
I prefer Chimay Red over Chimay blue. It is mellow and full of flavor. A t really good Belgian ale. The flavor does seem to dissipate quickly at the finish so it loses some pts for that.
Bottle. Reddish colour. Nice fruity aroma. Sweet and smooth taste. Very good.

Its still daylight outside and Im still inside.  Pours from 33cl bottle into Chimay tulip glass with very thin head; galaxies of small bubbles, really.  A little darker than grandmas apple cider.  Waxy and fizzy.  Fine.
330ml bottle. Yeasty aroma which translates largely into the taste. Slightly heavy body. Overall, a very good tasting beer.
330 ml bottle a brown colored beer with a white head aroma malts dry fruits caramel spicy and hops flavor malts dry fruits caramel spicy yeast and hops

Bottle. Brownish pour with a monster foamy light tan head. Aroma is yeast, caramel, and light apricot. Body is semi light but creamy. Some carbonation. Flavor is also caramel malt with a touch of fruit acidity. Nice brew.

33cl. bottle from a local beer retailer. It pours a murky brown liquid with some amber tones (and some ruby as it evolves) and many little yeast spots, with a gigantic consistent and pillowy beige head (tainted brown by a nice yeast sediment) that lasts beautifully throughout the beer and leaves some good lacing. The aroma is mostly malty, with caramel, brown sugar, some hints of banana and a slight citrusy hoppiness. There is also a good deal of roastiness and bready yeasts. It tastes kind of likewise, but intenser and more complex, some dried fruits suddenly appearing as well as a faint brandy-like touch. A nice spiciness is also there. It is medium sweet, a little sour and has a pleasant notable bitterness. In the mouth it feels thick and mildly carbonated, with little bubbles coming alive inside the mouth, very slightly prickling the tongue. The body is medium, giving the brew more drinkability. It finishes rather dry and bitter, with a sweet caramelly and nutty finish along with some floral and citrusy hoppiness. The presentation is smart and very trappist-like. I love it; cant help it. It might be somewhat overrated (not much, though), but the feelings towards some beers go beyond the metrics. A nice way to celebrate my 200 ratings.
Bière rousse brunâtre de 7 % dalcool. Elle possède un goût simple, léger arrière goût. Elle possède un léger goût boisé et amer. Ce nest pas un WOW !, mais elle est quand même bonne.

Chimay Red has a medium, beige head and a cloudy, rust-red appearance, with lots of carbonation. The aroma is of prunes and sharp spice. Taste is likewise of prunes, cinnamon spice, some banana, sweetness, and water. Some alcohol is picked up as well. Mouthfeel is medium, and Chimay Red finishes wet, refreshing, and delicious. This was actually more light-bodied and easy-drinking that I had suspected. Overall, this is a terrific beer, and I rate it outstanding. RJT.

large frothy off white head. good lacing. mostly diminishing. flat thick dark amberish-brown body. aroma: heavy malty, caramel, mild coffee, pear, nutmeg, vanilla, alcohol. if: heavy sweet  light bitter. ff: moderate sweet light bitter; long duration. palate: medium body, watery texture, medium carbonation, metallic and light alcoholic finish. forte dulçor caramelado e achocolatado, forte aquecimento alcoólico; bem doce, o álcool mascara outros sabores que senão o dulçor caramelado, toques frutados lembrando pêra pela metade do copo, aparenta mais q os 7%, baixa drinkability, lembra destilado em alguns momentos, 80s

33 cL bottle: Appearance is a cloudy brown with cream color head. Aroma is of yeast and bread notes. Flavor is quite simple, just a few malty notes along with a bit of Belgian yeast. Slightly over carbonated.

Bouteille 330 ml. 7%. Couleur ambrée-brune, effervescence vive, mousse beige pâle abondante. Arôme de levure belges et agrumes. En bouche, fruits, levure et très belge.....je commence à comprendre...peut-être que la Belgique All-Star, nest pas totalement pour moi ? Dunno...Charlevoix du Québec Dominus Vobiscum BEAUCOUP plus gouteuse. En tk............

33 cl bottle @ Lasse Autios Herrgård, Ropnäs, Vasa. Rated on 27.9.2008
Aroma has some banana, aged fruits, yeast and spices. Flavour is richly grainy and has some sweetish malt. Good dubbel but still I see no reason to buy it again.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2013 Nice trappist. Considerably better than Chimay Bleue.

Rerating 30.6.2013. Aroma of syrup, sugar, cognac. Copper colour, white head. Slightly oily.

Wow, a very nice dubbel. Aroma is yeasty, bready, light pepper, and light apricots with even lighter banana. Poured a nice red/brown cloudy color with an off white head. The taste was bready, sweet, and malty with light bitterness on the end. The mouth feel was nice and creamy. An excellent trappist dubbel I would recommend to anyone.

Would have been a much better beer if it wasnt for that darn palate which I suspected to be much heavier since it is one of the only seven Trappist beers. Not at all bad, nice bit of bitterness which is the strongest aspect of the overall week aftertaste. Aroma is great, very fruity and the beer looks nice and red. Good beer but not exactly what I hoped it would be.

Pours red/brown with a big foaming white head. Nose is yeast, red wine, malt, dried fruit (apricot, pineapple etc) and perfumey floral notes. Taste is tropical dried fruit, brown sugar and creaminess. Really nice and thoroughly well balanced Belgian beer.
UPDATED: JUL 19, 2011 Couleur orange cuivre avec beaucoup deffervescence. Plus légère que la Chimay bleue avec ses notes dabricots et de prunes.
Pours copper with a beige head. Aroma is roasted caramel and light dried fruit. Flavour is caramel, roasted notes and dried fruit.

Ahh chimay - the biere that introduced us to trappistisme. Cant believe Im finally getting around to rating this guy. Pours a lighter shade of dark brown. Less head than I remember. A great balance of fruitiness and dark sugars ensues. Well done.

Amber brown color with an off-white head that remains. A yeasty, malty nose. Mix of hazelnut, floral perfume and a hint vanilla. Malty and yeasty with caramel final. Strong alcohol % that you dont taste. Very nicely done. Ok its a Chimay. Do I want to be a monk? Well...

Deep, but not impenetrable brown and gives a voluminous creamy white head that leaves excellent lace and takes a white to settle. The aromas are of powdered chocolate, cinnamon, brioche and full, lush stonefruit. Those chocolate and baking flavours hit first and then dehydrated apricot in muesli. Also nutty almond and  brazil nuts dance on the palate of this creamy, sexy ale. The finish is one of dessert and pistachio. There is nothing not to like.
Medium brown in color. A nice head that dissipated quickly.  Aroma is chocolatey and nutty and the taste matches perfectly.  Smooth taste from start to finish with excellent flavors throughout.

Im a bit disappointed.  Rather than complex it feels like more of a flavor competition.  I dont think Id drink this again.  Too much bread, bananas and cereal in the mouth, too much grass on the aftertaste.  A heap of cheesey yeast still resides in my mouth.  Its not bad, but its not very good either.

Not quite up to the standard of the blue and the white, but still very enjoyable, not too malty for a dubbel, thank god, there is nothing worsen than a dubbel ruined because nits too malty. Very enjoyable.

Poured a light brown and coppery color, quite transparent and bubbly. Had a thick head that dissipated fairly quickly. It smelled of fruit, hops, some malt and a slight bit of grass. Its taste had a very smooth and moderately strong malt profile, seemed like mediums to dark roasts. It was slightly sweet and tasted of fruit and had a fairly strong bitter hop finish, but not as strong as an IPA. This was a good beer, darker flavor than I expected. It lacked the complexity youd expect but it is very smooth.

Poured from 330ml bottle into snifter glass. Cloudy brown-red colour, large off-white head that falls away relatively quickly and leaves little to no lacing. A big aroma of sweetly sharp malts, caramel, multiple fruits like orange and spices. Taste dominated by malt, caramel and dark fruits, as well as a toasty edge. Mouthfeel is a little rough and in some parts watery, which detracts from the drinkability. Medium body with medium-to-high carbonation. Overall a mostly enjoyable beer, but far from a "wow!" beer. Seems a somewhat straight forward abbey dubbel.
Its a good beer but i just didnt like it very much. Mouthfeel isnt how i like it.
bread, nuts, toast, golden, hazy, light brown foam,light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish,

Glass at Den Tatoverede Enke, Copenhagen. Hazy orange with a two fingers thick, creamy, light brown head. Wooden, spicy Belgian yeast aroma. Sweet, spicy, acidic and light earthy flavor. Medium body. Dryish mouth.

Bottle from Tesco poured into a Westmalle glass.  Very dark red, with a well formed and generous head.  Tastes fruity, slightly sweet, its a little less comples a brew than I was expecting.
The aroma is rich, hoppy and fruity, nice.  Nice on the palate, though not as good as the Blaauw.

Tasted in Tatoverede Enke, Copenhagen. Pours hazy golden with a big creamy off-white head. Lively carbonated.Aroma of dark sweet fruits, good malty sweetness. Taste is light sweet, malty with some alcohol presence, port wine and some nice spices, good choice. Complex and simple.
Aroma of.plums, yeast and malts.  Pours a hazy red with a bubbly head.  Tastes of sugar cane, wheat and tasty yeast.  Its the tastiest glass of bread Ive had in a while.

11.2 oz. bottle. Deep hazy amber and mahogany color, nearly opaque, huge light-tan head. Fresh floral and herbal aroma, yet quite subdued. Taste is bitter, earthy, with a bit of astringency. Complex, maybe a little messy? Dry finish. Weird aftertaste is reminding me of mold, just a little bit. Its been a while since Ive had a Chimay product, and I remember liking them better. Anyway, this brew is fine, but many other Belgian ales are more exciting. Try the small bottle first.
As advertised... very silky going down, bitter in the end.  Was hoping for more complexity... seems a bit mild for my liking.  Have had before, but will have to try again.
33cl. Dark Amber color with a great aroma a very clean crisp spicy brew. The fruity aromas where wonderful this is a very good brew and would love to visit the acutal brewery one day.
Pours red-brown, slight haze. Thin head, persisting. Nose of caramel and orange peel, yeast. Very creamy in the mouth, caramel is coming back slightly. Very long aftertaste sugar bread (?).

750 corked n caged bottle 2010 vintage- The cork popped out like a champagne cork, massively pressurized- Pours cloudy dark orange with a suprisingly thin head and poor lacework. The aroma makes up for the appearance, its Belgian sugar, yeast, banana, and tart. The flavor is also sugar, not too tart, figs, banana, clove, smooth and sessionable.
